loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of onions, tomatoes, and potatoes in bulk.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 35-year-old Victoria K.. She is single with two children, ages 7 and 10. In 1995 Victoria established a milling business where she mills maize flour, the main ingredient in the local staple ugali. Victoria now requests a loan of $275 in order to purchase parts for her milling machine. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase parts for her milling machine.

loans.name: Mwanne

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 33-year-old Mwanne S.. She is single with two children, ages 5 and 6. In 2007 Mwanne established a shop selling food items. Mwanne has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA and now requests a loan of $875 in order to purchase a refrigerator for storing perishable items and soft drinks. She thanks you for your support.

Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guinness (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the sticks, but I’m sure they’re working on it!). All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania.

loans.name: Mwazani

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 42-year-old Mwazani M.. She is married with two children, ages 15 and 17. In 1990 Mwazani established a business selling tomatoes, and in 2000 another selling samosas (a filled, fried pocket). Mwazani has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA and now requests a loan of $700 in order to purchase additional stock and ingredients in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is an organization that is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania. Through leasing and leaseback, SELFINA provides a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. As they lack tangible collateral assets, they are termed not creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from that client, extends a loan to her, then leases back the same equipment. The process is called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.name: Bertha

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 47-year-old Bertha M.. She is married with three children, aged 18, 23, and 25.
 
In 2001 Bertha established a dairy business. Bertha has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requests a loan of $875 in order to purchase additional livestock and milking equipment. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is an organization that is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania. Through leasing and leaseback, SELFINA provides a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. As they lack tangible collateral assets, they are termed not creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from that client, extends a loan to her, then leases back the same equipment. The process is called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional cows and milking equipment.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam! This is 55-year-old Lucy M.. She is married with five children, ages between 19 and 37, and has two other dependents who are her nieces.
 
Lucy owns a poultry business and has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA. She now requests a loan of $525 in order to purchase additional chickens and expand their enclosure. She thanks you for your support.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. In fact, if you are a regular lender on kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku! "Who or what are kuku?" you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. 

First, they require little start-up capital. You can start with one or two and either add to them as you go or wait for them to multiple naturally. Second, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound. Third, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals? Prettier?), but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks and expand their enclosure (their vet has pronounced that they are suffering from stress from overcrowding).

loans.name: Leutogi

texts.en:
Leutogi is a 27-year-old single mother with one child from the village of Papaigalagala. This is her second loan from SPBD in the amount of USD$475. She is a hard-working lady. She sells her ice cakes (homemade popsicles) from her home to village people seven days a week.

Leutogi earns around US$ 60 a day from her business. She is now applying for a loan of USD$475 for expanding of her ice cake business and also for renovating her home.

loans.use: To buy plastic bags, Koolaid, sugar, and also cement, sand, lumber, etc

loans.name: Faau

texts.en:
Thirty-nine-year-old Faau is divorced from her husband and she has three children in school. She is responsible for looking after her children by herself. She joined SPBD last year, receiving her first loan of WST$ 750, and started a business. Now she is applying for her second loan in the amount of US$475 and is looking forward to expanding her ice cake (homemade popsicle) business.

Faau sells her ice cakes 7 days a week and earns about US$ 50 daily from from them. That’s helping her to send her children to school and with other family expenses like monthly bills for food, etc., and also allows her to make her loan repayments in a timely manner.

loans.use: To buy plastic bags, Koolaid, and sugar for her popsicles and also cement, sand, timber, and pop corn oil

loans.name: Ao

texts.en:
Ao F. is a mother aged fifty-four from the village of Tulaele. She runs a vegetable garden business. She’s a very energetic woman who has put much effort into trying to improve her business.

Ao has a very good loan history with SPBD and wishes to continue to stay in the program for more financial assistance to her business. With her requested loan, she plans to further improve her little market garden business.

loans.use: Purchase pesticides and more seeds

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Lumanai

texts.en:
Lumanai is from the village of Manunu. She is one of our oldest members and one of those most reliable and trustworthy. She is running a Cattle Farm as well as her plantation. She is forty years of age and married with five kids. Her husband does not work and therefore there is no regular income for her and the family besides what she earns.

Lumanai is looking at improving her businesses through this loan and also some part of it will be used for house improvement and paying school fees for her children. She is a hard-working and active woman and she is hopes in future to get a higher loan amount for more improvement so her family will prosper.

loans.use: buy wire, chemicals, and tools for the plantation

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Ana Silvia

texts.es:
Ana Silvia has a business where she sells products for daily consumption, including chicken by the pound, eggs, and vegetables. She has had this business for six years and has kept up her location during this time. Her family consists of three children, of whom two currently depend on her economically. This drove her to start the business, since her expenses increased as her children grew. It was more than necessary to have extra income to be able to help her husband with the expenses. The financing has helped her supply her business little by little. Her main objective is to invest in products that are most in demand since she knows that her microbusiness is one of the most important sources of income for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Tiene un negocio de venta de artículos para el consumo diario entre ellos pollo por libras ,huevos verduras y otros , el negocio lo tiene desde hace seis años y a conservado su ubicación en todo este tiempo , su grupo familiar lo componen tres hijos delos cuales dos en la actualidad dependen económicamente de la solicitante , lo que la impulso a emprender el negocio es que conforme fueron creciendo sus hijos se fueron incrementando los gastos de ellos y se era mas que necesario el poder tener ingresos extras para poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos , los financiamientos le han ayudado a poder ir surtiendo poco a poco su negocio , su objetivo primordial es la inversión en los productos que mas le solicitan ya que reconoce que su microempresa es una de las fuentes mas importantes de ingresos en su familia.

loans.use: She will buy vegetables, chicken by the pound, beef, and basic grains, which are the products that are most in demand at her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Apoyo Integral - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Lotolagi

texts.en:
Lotolagi M. is a fifty-three-year-old lady from the village of Manunu. She is running a Pop Corn Business and she is also running a big plantation which covers almost four acres of their land. She grows taro and bananas only and she works from Monday to Friday. She only goes to the market three days of the week and she manages to bring in about US$120 a day so about US$ 400 a week.

Lotolagi is very active and she is working hard to make sure that her children will have a good education and a better future life than she has had. She is planning on spending this loan improving her business, and she is hoping to spend her next loan on improving her house.

loans.use: buy chemicals, an axe, knives, and a wheelbarrow for her plantation

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Miguel Angel

texts.es:
Señor Meléndez currently lives in one of the colonies of La Libertad in El Salvador. He has two children who have helped him a lot with his business. He has had this business for eight years, in which he sells school and office supplies. It has given him the economic means necessary to support his family, and he has a lot of experience in this trade. He has been very enterprising, since he started with a small inventory of some notebooks and a couple of books. He also used to depend on the credits that the large bookstore suppliers gave him, even though they provided him with items at higher prices. Now, the loans have helped him not to depend on these suppliers and to be able to obtain better offers by paying cash.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

El señor Meléndez, vive actualmente en una de las colonias de la Libertad en El Salvador sus hijos son dos los cuales colaboran en gran manera en su negocio , el se a dedicado desde hace ocho años a la venta de artículos escolares y papelería para oficina, este le a dado los medios económicos necesarios para poder mantener a su familia el habla con mucha experiencia en este rubro , a sido muy emprendedor con su negocio ya que comenzó con poco en su inventario unos cuantos cuadernos y par de libros además dependía de los créditos que le daban los proveedores de librerías mas fuertes, y ellos aunque le proporcionaban los artículos pero con precios mas altos en la actualidad los financiamientos le han servido para no depender de estos proveedores y poder conseguir mejores ofertas al comprar de contado.

loans.use: This credit will help him be able to supply new lines of school supplies like notebooks, which are the highest-selling items of this new school season.

payments.comment: This entrepreneur has prepaid the balance on his loan. He is grateful for your loan and appreciates your support.

loans.name: Filomena

texts.en:
Filomena L. is forty-one years of age and comes from the village of Saletele Fagaloa. She runs a handicrafts business working to make her crafts from Monday until Friday when she goes to the market to sell the goods. Her husband is not a man with good education but he is skilled in carving and designing traditional handicrafts such as Samoan canoes, tanoa (large, carved, hardwood bowls), fue (a traditional fly brush), and such.

Filomena is on her second loan now, and she is hoping to use this loan on not only improving her business but also to improve her house. She is one of the good and honest ladies in our Center and she is hoping for more loans in the future for further improvement. She is active not only in her timely re-payments but also in Center meetings.

loans.use: Business / home improvement

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for South Pacific Business Development (SPBD) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en:
Elisapeta is a member of our programme who has been with us for a long time. She is from the village of Manono Tai and she is running a fishing business. She has five children, four of whom are attending the village primary school. She is one of our active members and she is reliable and trustworthy.

Her husband does not have other work so he is the one that is helping her to run the business. The husband goes fishing up to five days of the week, depending on the weather. If the fishing goes well then Elisapeta will now go to the market to sell the catch instead of selling it in front of her house beside the road. She is on her fifth loan and she is looking to receive more loans from SPBD in the future to further expand their little business.

loans.use: Business expansion & home improvement

Mrs. Heng S., 32, makes baskets and typically earns about $2 each day. Her husband is a mobile construction foreman who earns about $6 per day. Mrs. Heng S. has four children. Two of them are enrolled in school and two are too young to attend school.

She would like to use this loan to to purchase bamboo to make more baskets to sell. She will use some of the loan to build the rest of her house and install tiles and a roof to protect the family from flooding during the rainy season.

loans.use: Purchase bamboo to create more baskets to sell

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Heng Sambou start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

In the picture, Amina is the first from the right.

payments.comment: This business was accidently posted with a loan term of 16 months instead of 16 weeks. Tujijenge is apologizing for this mistake. The loan term has now been completed as of this month and Riiziki group has repaid the loan successfully

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women.  Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.name: Eisha

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam!  This is 30 year-old Eisha N..  She is married with three children aged 7 and 9, and has two other dependents who are her niece and nephew.
 
In 2000, Eisha established a livestock business and in 2007, added a grocery business to her workload.  Eisha has already received and successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a loan of $850 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk.  She thanks you for your support.

Eisha is a perfect example of why microfinance works and why the large majority of clients repay their loans.  A lot of people who hear about microfinance (or kiva.org) for the first time, ask anxiously, “But how do you make sure people pay back?  Won’t they just take the money?”  The implication is that the clientele who access microfinance (usually the ‘poor’) are less trustworthy, efficient or educated than ‘ordinary’ people.  Whether or not this is true is somewhat irrelevant for a number of reasons.  

Firstly, most MFIs have due diligence processes in place to assess client risk, as well as measures such as collateral arrangements and group lending (where a defaulted loan is borne by the group as a whole) to address this risk.  More important than any of these deterrents, however, is an incentive.  The incentive clients have to start a business, build a business, and repay their loan so that they can get another and another and another… The incentive to have on-going access to financial services from which they had previously been excluded.

loans.use: To purchase additional livestock and grocery stocks.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam!  This is 27 year-old Zainabu L..  She is married with two children aged 1 and 7.  In 1998 Zainabu established a used clothing business and now requires a loan of $275 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk.

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages.  These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything western or modern.  Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry.  There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress; however, the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of used clothing in bulk.

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Sokheng, 46, is a widow with one daughter. Sokheng began farming in 1985, and grows tomatoes, corns, and papayas. She also has a business weaving silk.

She lives with her mother and her daughter on an island in the Mekong River, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh. Her daughter is studying in the local school. When she has free time, she helps her mother with weaving at home.

Sokheng requests this loan of $700, her second loan from MAXIMA. She will use this money to expand her farming business.

loans.use: Expand farming business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam!  This is 29 year-old Mwajuma R..  She is married with two children.  In 2005, Mwajuma established a hairdressing and clothing business.  Mwajuma has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a loan of $850 in order to purchase additional stock and equipment.  She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA
SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing.  Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets.  This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women.  Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her hairdressing and clothing businesses.

loans.name: Sroy

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Sroy (age 45) and her husband, Mr. Peng Po (age 51) have been married since1979. Sroy and her husband have a business producing silk. Sroy has been a silk weaver since 1979. It’s a skill she learned from her mother. Her husband has been a silk weaver since 2006.

They have six children—four sons and two daughters. Four of their sons are working, and their two daughters are studying in the local school. Sroy and her family live in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh.

Sroy requests this loan of $300, her second loan from MAXIMA. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay for the preparation of her loom.

loans.use: Buying silk material for weaving

loans.name: Patrasia

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam!  This is 38 year-old Patrasia C..  She is married with three children aged 9, 17, and 20.  In 2003, Patrasia established a café selling local food and drinks, and now requires a loan of $275 in order to purchase ingredients and stocks of soft drinks in bulk. 

When you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is ‘restaurant’ or ‘café’, you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is.  A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches with the sky as a ceiling.  Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be.  The food is all local - rice, ugali (a hot sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked savoury banana) - and all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients and stocks of soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Samnang

texts.en:
Miss. C. Samnang, 40, is single. She lives with her old mother and her older sister in a small village across the Mekong River about twenty kilometers north of Phnom Penh. Samnag and her sister learned to weave several years ago from a neighbor. After working for a year, their skill level was good enough to start weaving independently. Now they've been weaving on their own for three years and each one has a loom.

Samnang is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA, for the amount of $200. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and pay for the preparation of her loom.

loans.use: Buy silk materials and prepare loom

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mwanahawa

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam!  This is 35 year-old Mwanahawa M..  She is married with four children aged 9,12, 15, and 19.  In 2003, Mwanahawa established a soft drinks business and now requires a loan of $275 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. 

It is said that Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or ‘words’ in the world.  And it’s true.  Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness (Pepsi has made it to most African capitals, but not to the sticks.  I’m sure they’re working on it!).  The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing; a very cheap marketing tool!  All of which explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture - whether you’re the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Inviolather

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam!  This is 46 year-old Inviolather R..  She is married with two children, aged 16 and 21, and has two other dependents who are her nieces.
 
In 1990, Inviolather established a poultry business.  She has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now requires a loan of $600 in order to purchase additional chickens to raise and sell.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients.  In fact, if you are a regular lender on kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku.  Who or what are ‘kuku’, you may ask.  Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons. 

Firstly, they require little start-up capital.  You can start with one or two and either add to them as you go, or wait for them to multiply naturally!  

Secondly, they require little space, so sometimes you can just let them run around in your garden or compound.  

Thirdly, while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein.  

I’m sure there are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals? Prettier?), but this is all that time and space will allow.

loans.use: To purchase additional chicks to raise and sell.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sero Lease and Finance Ltd. (SELFINA) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Korn

texts.en:
Mrs. Korn K. S., age 27, works with her husband raising pigs and making medicinal rice wine. Together, they earn about $5 each day. They live with their young child, niece, and nephew in Siem Reap province in Cambodia.

She requests a loan of $400 in order to purchase more rice to produce wine, and to buy pig feed to supplement her livestock.

loans.use: Purchase pig feed, and more rice to produce medicinal wine.

payments.comment: Congrats! Your Kiva loan has been repaid early. Thank you for taking a sincere interest in helping Cambodian entrepreneurs like Korn Kim Seang start and sustain their businesses. Your willingness to share your financial resources has made a difference. We hope you continue to lend through CREDIT in the future. Sincerely, Joshua Benadum, CREDIT Intern, Phnom Penh Office.

loans.name: Pheng

texts.en:
Mr. H. Pheng, 37, and his wife, Mrs. Noun Kan, 28, have been married since 1995. Pheng and his wife have a restaurant in the village, and sell Chinese noodles, food, coffee, and drinks (pictured with their son in front of restaurant).

They have two children-- one son, one daughter. Their children are studying in the local school. Pheng and his family live along National Road number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Pheng is requesting his first loan from MAXIMA for $1,200. He plans to use this loan to expand his restaurant adding more tables and chairs so he can seat more customers. He will also add items to the menu, such as beer and wine. He needs to purchase kitchen equipment and tableware as well. By offering these specialty items, they will be able to earn a higher profit for the family.

loans.use: For improving restaurant

loans.name: Phov

texts.en:
Mrs. Phov S., age 42, is a housewife. Her husband is a fisherman, who earns about $4 each day. They have four children; one is employed at a golf course and three are enrolled in school.

She requests a loan of $300 to purchase fishing tools to assist her husband with his business. This will increase the family’s income and allow her to be able to pay for her children’s education.

loans.use: Purchase fishing tools

loans.name: Hoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Hoeun S. O., age 41, is a housewife. Her husband is a traveling construction foreman, who earns about $6 each day. She has six children; two are employed at a hotel, two are students, and the rest are married and live separately.

She requests a loan of $600 in order to purchase a fence around her house and build a clean toilet. She would use any remaining funds to purchase more construction tools for her husband’s business.

loans.use: Purchase construction supplies and build a fence and toilet at her home

loans.name: Phat

texts.en:
Mr. P. Phat, 46, and his wife, Mrs. Kong Somaly, 33, have been married since 1992. Phat and his wife have a farm not too far from their home. He grows a few kinds of spinach to sell in the market in Phnom Penh. He started his business in 2000.

They have three children—two sons and one daughter. One of his children is working in a garment factory, and the other two children are studying in the local school. He and his family live along National Road number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Phat requests this loan for $600; it is his third loan from MAXIMA. He will use this money to buy a water pumping machine and for supplies for growing vegetables.

loans.use: Buy a water pumping machine and supplies for growing vegetables

loans.name: Rindy

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Rindy, 39, is a widow with six children—two sons and four daughters. Two of her children work in a garment factory, three children attend the local school, and other child works on the farm. Her husband died many years ago. She and her family lives along National Road number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Rindy started her farm when she was young. Currently, she grows tomatoes to sell in the market. All her children help her on the farm whenever they have free time.

Ridy requests this loan for $200; it's her first loan request from MAXIMA. She will use this money to expand her tomatoes farm.

loans.use: Expand tomatoes farm

texts.en: We are Kisiwani Women's Group, a group of women entrepreneurs in the Buguruni area. We have been with Youth Self Employment Foundation as a group for the past year. Each of us sells vegetables and fruit in the Buguruni Market, one of Dar Es Salaam’s biggest municipal markets. We are jointly in need of US$ 2000, of which US$ 400 is meant for each one of our members, so that each can expand her business and help her family to prosper.

loans.use: expand our individual businesses to better meet our families' needs

Mrs. Phorn S., 44, is a widow and cooks food to sell to supplement the family's income, as well as cooking for her four employed children. Two children are laborers and two are waitresses. Mrs. Phorn S. is pictured with one of her sons.

She requests a loan of $500 in order to purchase a motorcycle to use for her family’s transportation. If she no longer has to pay for all her children’s transportation to work, she will be able to build up her family’s savings.

loans.use: Purchase a motorbike to save on the cost of her family's transportation

Mrs. Sov S., age 27, works with her husband running a butcher shop in her community. They sell pork and beef, and earn about $4 each day of profit. Her one child is too young to attend school.

Mrs. Sov S. requests a loan of $400 to increase the inventory of products to sell so she can meet the demands of the growing day-to-day business. She would like to expand her store so that she can sell more, and thus increase the income for her family. (The picture shows her husband because she was unavailable when the photograph was taken.)

texts.en:
We are Happness C., Saraha L., Arafa Shabani, Asma H. and Doris R., and together we make up the Mambo Club. We are engaged in various businesses in Buguruni Municipal market, including selling of fruit and vegetables, running little restaurants, and managing kiosks.

We are jointly in need of US$ 2000, which will be divided equally among us, so that each will receive US$ 400 to help expand her business.

loans.use: expand our various businesses to better serve our families

loans.use: To purchase more items to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: she needs the loan to purchase goods

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya owns a small business selling beautiful pictures and artwork at a little kiosk near one of the busy markets in Stryi, Ukraine. She works with artists from a nearby city, Lviv, and has developed a successful business selling quality artwork. Married with three children ages seven to twenty-five, she is an entrepreneurial-minded business owner with definite goals for the future.

In the spring, she would like to move her business to a new location. She plans to use part of her business income to complete some remodeling of the store before she moves. Natalya is also thinking of starting a new business in a different line of work - hair care - with a store called “Mobile Salon”.

Natalya has requested a loan of $800 to purchase new pictures to sell in her kiosk. She will be able to buy around 30 pictures to re-sell. We are excited for the opportunity to assist Natalya with her business and look forward to seeing where her endeavors will take her in the future.

loans.use: Purchase around 30 pictures for re-sale in her art kiosk

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is a single mother who supports her family with a small market business selling children’s toys. Irina’s business is located at an outdoor market in the city of Energodar in southern Ukraine near the beautiful Dnepr River. She has been self-employed for ten years and loves what she does. Her business has been a good source of income for her and her family and she’d like to continue developing it in the future.

Irina has requested a loan of $1000 so that she can purchase new toy inventory and continue to attract customers to her little kiosk. This is Irina’s sixth loan from Nadiya Ukraine. We are happy for this opportunity to continue helping her operate a successful business.

loans.use: Purchase inventory for her little toy kiosk

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana has a small business selling clothing items and footwear from her little outdoor market kiosk in Kamenka-Dneprovskaya, Ukraine. Tatyana, who is single, has had her business for about six years. She makes enough to support herself plus a little extra to help her two grown children. Her daughter recently got married and incurred some of the costs typically associated with weddings. Ukrainian weddings sometimes have celebrations lasting up to two days so they can be quite expensive.

Tatyana is a determined entrepreneur who would like to continue developing and growing her business. She has requested a six-month loan of $1000 to help purchase new inventory items so she can continue offering her customers attractive clothing and make good sales.

loans.use: Purchase inventory for her clothing kiosk

loans.name: Aida

texts.en: Aida is a 24-year-old unemployed woman. She is married and has two children who are 7 and 3 years old. Her husband does seasonal work which is related to forestry. In that period, their monthly income is 500 KM (about US$375), but in the period when he does not work, the goats are their only source of income. Aida is not a new client; this is her second loan from Women For Women International in the amount of US$775. She used the first loan to buy goats. Thanks to the milk products of her goats, Aida can provide money and food for her family. Aida thinks that with a larger number of goats, she would be able to improve her life and the lives of her children.

loans.use: Buying goats and food supplies

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Derviša

texts.en: Derviša is a 29-year-old woman who lives in a small village near Sarajevo who breeds strawberries. She used her first loan in the amount of 500 KM (about US$375) to buy seedlings and technical equipment. She is married and her husband does seasonal work, usually in the summer. They have two children who are 8 and 3 years old, and Derviša's biggest wish is to provide good living conditions and to secure a good future for them.

loans.use: Buying seedlings and technical equipment.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Zene za Zene, a partner of Women for Women International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Asenciona's Group

texts.es:
Yanet, Elizabeth and Asenciona have belonged to the Communal Bank Los Laureles for 8, 1 and 10 years respectively. In their communal bank they learned to be puctual, responsible, how to manage their business, and how to tend to their customers.

Yanet is 37 years old and has 6 children. She sells food at the association Los Mecanicos (the mechanics) during the day, and sells anticuchos (Peruvian meat grilled skewers) at night. She has been doing both activities as a street vendor for 6 years. On her part, Elizabeth is 23 years old and has a small son. Elizabeth has been selling firewood for a year. Meanwhile, Asenciona is 54 years old, has 4 children, and has had a general store for 24 years.

Yanet, Elizabeth and Asenciona need loans for 400 soles each, which they will invest in buying rice, noodles, potato, condiments, firewood, oil, milk, cookies, candy, chocolate, gum.

They will use their savings for their children's education or in case of an emergency. The dreams of Yanet, Elizabeth, and Asencions are to have a larger business, that their children go to college, setting up a car repair shop together with her husband, and set up a tailor's shop.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Yanet, Elizabeth y Asenciona pertenecen al Banco Comunal Los Laureles desde hace 8, 1, 10 años respectivamente. En su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser puntuales, responsables, como manejar su negocio y atender a los clientes.

Yanet tiene 37 años y 6 hijos, y vende comida durante el día en la asociación Los Mecánicos y por las noches vende anticuchos. Ambas actividades las realiza ambulantemente desde hace 6 años. Por otro lado Elizabeth tiene 23 años y 1 hijo pequeño. Elizabeth vende leña en su casa desde hace 1 año. Mientras que Asenciona tiene 54 años y 4 hijos, y tiene una tienda de abarrotes desde hace 24 años.

Yanet, Elizabeth y Asenciona necesitan préstamos de 400 soles cada una, que serán invertidos en la compra de arroz, fideo, papa, condimentos, leña, aceite, leche, galletas, caramelos, chocolates, chicles.

Sus ahorros los utilizarán para la educación de sus hijos y para alguna emergencia. Los sueños de Yanet, Elizabeth y Asenciona son tener un negocio más grande, que sus hijos realicen estudios superiores, poner un taller mecánico junto a su esposo e implementar una sastrería.

loans.use: Yanet, Elizabeth and Asenciona need loans for 400 soles each, which they will invest in buying rice, noodles, potato, condiments, firewood, oil, milk, cookies, candy, chocolate, gum.

loans.name: Mercedes Rocio's Group

texts.es:
Angelica is 36 years old and has 2 children, Mercedes is 24 years old and has a child, whereas Ana is 35 years old and has 4 children. They have belonged to the Communal Bank Alegria Huamanga (Huamanga Joy) for 3, 2, and 1 year respectively. They say that in their communal bank they learned about responsibility, how to prevent illnesses, sharing, how to relate to their partners, and leadership. They mention that in their communal bank they are very united and supportive of each other.

Angelica has had a seamstress' shop for 5 years. She also works on carpentry. On her part, Mercedes, together with her husband, owned a Marisqueria (selling prepared shellfish and fish), business which she started 7 years ago, with lots of troubles. Currently, her business has grown and she wants to open more branches and other businesses. Meanwhile, Ana is a professional nurse working as a nutritional consultant and selling natural products Omnilife.

Angelica, Mercedes and Ana need loans for 600 soles, 400 soles, and 600 soles respectively, which will be invested in buying tablecloths, flatware, natural products, and buying a circular machine.

They will use their savings to build a house and increase their business' capital. The dreams of Angelica, Mercedes and Ana are to keep getting preparation, that their children grow to be professionals, having all comforts, own a house, and to expand their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Angélica tiene 36 años y 2 hijos, Mercedes tiene 24 años y 1 hijo, mientras Ana tiene 35 años y 4 hijos y ellas pertenecen al Banco Comunal Alegría Huamanga desde hace 3, 2, y 1 año respectivamente. Ellas dicen que en su Banco Comunal aprendieron la responsabilidad, a prevenir enfermedades, a compartir, cómo relacionarse con su pareja y el liderazgo. Ellas mencionan que en su Banco Comunal son bien unidas y solidarias. Angélica tiene su taller de confección de prendas de vestir, actividad que realiza en su casa desde hace 5 años, y además Angélica junto a su esposo tienen una carpintería. Por otro lado Mercedes junto a su esposo tienen una Marisquería (venta de comida preparada de mariscos y pescado), negocio que inició hace 7 años y tuvieron muchos problemas económicos. En la actualidad su negocio ha crecido y su deseo es tener sucursales y otros negocios más. Mientras que Ana es enfermera de profesión, hace consejería de nutrición y vende productos naturales Omnilife. Angélica, Mercedes y Ana necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 400 soles y 600 soles respectivamente, que serán invertidos en la compra de manteles, cubiertos, vajilla, productos naturales y para la compra de una máquina circular. Sus ahorros los utilizaran en la construcción de su casa, para incrementar el capital de su negocio, Los sueños de Angélica, Mercedes y Ana son seguir capacitándose, que sus hijos sean profesionales, tener todas las comodidades, casa propia y ampliar sus negocios.

loans.use: Angelica, Mercedes and Ana need loans for 600 soles, 400 soles, and 600 soles respectively, which will be invested in buying tablecloths, flatware, natural products, and buying a circular machine.

loans.name: Flora Cirila's Group

texts.es:
Flora, Margoth and Julia have belonged to the Alegria Huamanga Communal Bank since they were 4, 1, and 1 respectively. They mention that at their Communal Bank they learned the values of saving, how to prevent sicknesses and how to care for their children. Flora is married, she is 47 and has 5 children, she works at the fair and sells groceries and fruits. At the fairs she buys grains and processes them, converting them into hulled wheat and flour products that are sold in the Nery Garcia market, an activity that she began 30 years ago. On the other hand, Margoth is single and is 21. Margoth works as a waitress in a seafood restaurant and also helps her mother in her business of selling fruits. While Julia is married, she is 48 and has 7 children. Julia has sold vegetables traveling in the April 12 Market for 30 years and furthermore, together with her husband and children makes beautiful weavings on the loom, products they sell in the Santa Clara market and bring to Lima. Flora, Margoth and Julia need loans of 1000 soles, 400 soles, 400 soles, that they will invest in the purchase of broad beans, peas, barley, peach, banana, orange, apple, grape, rice, sugar, noodles, thread, wool, carrots, onion. Their savings they will utilize to increase their capital and settle the expenses of their children’s studies. The dreams of Flora, Margoth and Julia are to have a bigger business that their children will be professionals, finalize their studies and have their own homes.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Flora, Margoth y Julia pertenecen al Banco Comunal Alegría Huamanga desD. hace 4, 1, 1 año respectivamente. Ellas mencionan que en su Banco Comunal aprendieron los valores, a ahorrar, a prevenir enfermedades y cómo cuidar a los hijos. Flora es casada, tiene 47 años y 5 hijos, y además es feriante y venD. abarrotes y frutas. En las ferias compra cereales y los procesa, convirtiéndolos en morón, trigo partido, harina, productos que son vendidos en el mercado Nery García, actividad que realiza desD. hace 30 años. Por otro lado Margoth es soltera y tiene 21 años. Margot trabaja como mesera en una cebichería y además ayuda a su mamá en su negocio D. venta D. frutas. Mientras que Julia es casada, tiene 48 años y 7 hijos. Julia venD. verduras en forma ambulatoria en el mercado 12 D. abril desD. hace 30 años y, además, junto a su esposo e hijos hacen bellos tejidos en telar como frazadas, pasadizos; productos que venD. en el mercado Santa Clara y lleva a Lima. Flora, Margoth y Julia necesitan préstamos D. 1000 soles, 400 soles, 400 soles, que serán invertidos en la compra haba, arveja, papa, cebada, durazno, plátano, naranja, manzana, uva, arroz, azúcar, fideo, hilo, lana, zanahoria, cebolla. Sus ahorros los utilizarán para incrementar su capital y solventar los gastos D. estudio D. sus hijos. Los sueños D. Flora, Margoth y Julia son tener un negocio más granD., que sus hijos sean profesionales, finalizar sus estudios y tener casa propia.

loans.use: Flora, Margoth and Julia need loans of 1000 soles, 400 soles, 400 soles, that they will invest in the purchase of broad beans, peas, barley, peach, banana, orange, apple, grape, rice, sugar, noodles, thread, wool, carrots, onion.

loans.name: Florencia's Group

texts.es:
Florencia, Celedonia and Martha have belonged to Los Laureles Comunal Bank for 1 year. In their Communal bank they learned to be punctual, responsible, to love their fellows, and to save. Florencia is married, 39, and has 3 children and sells vegetables in the markets of the ayacuchan jungle and at the markets, she brings fruits to sell in the Nery Garcia market. On the other hand, Celedonia lives with her significant other, she is 48 and has 6 children and has a restaurant. Previously she was selling shoes at wholesale in the Santa Clara market, and her sales she made through credit and one of her clients left without paying; with the capital that she lost she had to start over with the business of selling food. While Martha sells “salchipollos” (fries and chicken nuggets) in the doorway of her mother-in-law’s house, an activity that she has been doing for 2 years. Furthermore Martha weaves cards that she sells to friends and relatives. Florencia, Celedonia and Martha need loans of 1000 soles, 1000 soles and 400 soles that they will invest in the purchase of chickens, rice, sugar, potatoes, celery, leeks, carrots, barley, cereals, oil, noodles, milk, sodas, beers, disposable plates and napkins. The dreams of Florencia, Celedonia and Martha are to buy land, construct a house, purchase a car to be able to transport their goods and that their children will be professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Florencia, Celedonia y Martha pertenecen al Banco Comunal Los Laureles desde hace 1 año. En su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser puntuales, responsables, a querer a sus semejantes y a ahorrar. Florencia es casada, tiene 39 años y 3 hijos y vende verduras en las ferias de la selva ayacuchana y de las ferias trae frutas que vende en el mercado Nery García. Por otro lado Celedonia es conviviente, tiene 48 años y 6 hijos y tiene su restaurante. Anteriormente vendía zapatillas al por mayor en el mercado Santa Clara, y sus ventas las hacia al crédito y unos de sus clientes se fue sin pagarle, con lo cual perdió su capital y tuvo que iniciar de nuevo con el negocio de venta de comida. Mientras que Martha vende salchipollos en la puerta de la casa de su suegro, actividad que realiza desde hace 2 años. Además Martha teje carteras que vende a amigos y familiares. Florencia, Celedonia y Martha necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 1000 soles y 400 soles que serán invertidos en la compra de pollo, arroz, azúcar, papa, apio, poro, zanahoria, arveja, cereales, aceite, fideo, leche, gaseosas, cerveza, platos descartables, servilletas. Los sueños de Florencia, Celedonia y Martha son comprar un terreno, construir su casa, comprar un carro para poder transportar su mercadería y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: Florencia, Celedonia and Martha need loans of 1000 soles, 1000 soles and 400 soles that they will invest in the purchase of chickens, rice, sugar, potatoes, celery, leeks, carrots, barley, cereals, oil, noodles, milk, sodas, beers, disposable plates and napkins.

loans.name: Bertha Yony's Group

texts.es:
Fernandina is 30 and has 2 children, Bertha is 34 and has 4 children, while Flora is 42 and has 5 children. They have belonged to Los Laureles Communal Bank for 2, 2 and 1 year respectively. In their Communal Bank they were taught to save, how to have understanding in her home, how to educate their children and how to manage money. Fernandina sells animals such as sheep, pigs, chickens, rams, that she fattens up herself and sells in the Nery Garcia market and in Lima. On the other hand, Bertha sells groceries, and fruits in a kiosk near her house. At the beginning she was only selling fruit by traveling but with the savings she made a small kiosk and amplified her business. Bertha has plans to open a bar in her house. While Flora sells food in a location that she rents. Fernandina, Bertha and Flora need loans of 600 soles, 200 soles, and 400 soles that will be invested in the purchase of pigs, chickens, sugar, rice, oil, noodles and to start their bar. The dreams of Fernandina, Bertha and Flora are that their children have a good education, to have a their own house, and their own premise for business.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Fernandina tiene 30 años y 2 hijos, Bertha tiene 34 años y 4 hijos, mientras que Flora tiene 42 años y 5 hijos. Ellas pertenecen al Banco Comunal Los Laureles desde hace 2, 2 y 1 año respectivamente. En su Banco Comunal le enseñaron a ahorrar, tener comprensión en el hogar, cómo educar a los hijos y cómo manejar el dinero. Fernandina vende animales como ovinos, cerdos, gallinas, carneros, que ella misma engorda y vende en el mercado Nery García y en Lima. Por otro lado Bertha vende abarrotes, frutas en un kiosco cerca de su casa. Al inicio solo vendía frutas ambulantemente pero con los ahorros que reunió hizo un pequeño kiosco y amplió su negocio. Bertha tiene planeado abrir un bar en su casa. Mientras que Flora vende comida en un local que es alquilado. Fernandina, Bertha y Flora necesitan préstamos de 600 soles, 200 soles y 400 soles que serán invertidos en la compra de cerdos, gallinas, carneros, azúcar, arroz, aceite, fideo y para implementar su bar. Los sueños de Fernandina, Bertha y Flora son que sus hijos tengan una buena educación, tener casa propia y un local propio.

loans.use: Fernandina, Bertha and Flora need loans of 600 soles, 200 soles, and 400 soles that will be invested in the purchase of pigs, chickens, sugar, rice, oil, noodles and to start their bar.

loans.name: Daniela's Group

texts.es:
Justina is 44 years old, Daniela is 56 years old, and Estela is 65 years old. They are all part of the Community Bank of Your Angel Lucy and have been part of the bank for 7, 8, and 5 years respectively. In the bank, they were trained to run their businesses and save.

Justina sells spices (condiments) in the “Market: April 12th.” She began her business with a loan for $50 and little by little grew to have more merchandise and clientel.

Daniela sells food in the Santa Clara Market. She joined the Community Bank due to the invitations from her friends.

Estela sews clothing and sells it in the community fairs. Estela began her business with $2 of savings.

Justina, Daniela and Estela need a loan of S/. 1,000.00 ($350.00), S/. 600 ($200.00) and S/. 600 ($200.00) which will be invested in cinnamon, pepper, cumin, red chile, yellow chile, rice, potatoes, noodles, sugar, cloth, thread and other accessories. Justina, Daniela and Estela dram of constructing their own homes, raising their children to be professionals, and opening up time for relaxation in their homes.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

Justina tiene 44 años, Daniela tiene 56 años, mientras que Estela tiene 65 años, ellas pertenecen al Banco Comunal Tu Ángel Lucy desD. hace 7, 8 y 5 años respectivamente. En su Banco Comunal les enseñaron a como administrar sus negocios y a ahorrar. Justina venD. especerías (condimentos para cocinar) en el mercado 12 D. abril, Justina cuenta que inició con un préstamo D. 50 dólares y poco a poco fue creciendo; actualmente tiene más mercadería y clientes. Por otro lado Daniela venD. comida en el mercado Santa Clara y llegó al Banco Comunal por invitación D. una amiga. Mientras que Estela confecciona prendas D. vestir y los venD. a los feriantes, Estela comenta que inició con 2 dólares D. ahorros. Justina, Daniela y Estela necesitan préstamos D. 1000 soles, 600 soles y 600 soles que serán invertidos en la compra D. canela, pimienta, comino, ají colorado, ají amarillo, arroz, papa, fideo, azúcar, telas, hilos y otros accesorios. Los sueños D. Justina, Daniela y Estela son construir su casa, que sus hijos sean buenos profesionales y para abrir un recreo en su casa.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for sale in each woman's respective business.

loans.name: Marina's Group

texts.es:
Mayra, Marina and Edith have belonged to the Community Bank of Your Angel Lucy for 3, 6 and 3 years respectively. They say that in the bank they have learned to be responsible, united and punctual.

Mayra is a 23 year old single mother with one child. She sells clothing by order. Her sales are maD. on credit which she recoups daily. Mayra has been doing this work for 2 years.

Marina is 50 years old and has four children. She has been baking bread for 3 years and sells them in the “Market: April 12th.” To begin with she sold gelatins and after receiving a loan from the Community Bank began her bakery.

Edith is 21 years old and has one child. Edith, along with her husband, have ran a bar for the last 5 years. The bar is located in the center of the city.

Mayra, Marina and Edith need a loan of S/. 1,400 ($450.00), S/. 1,000 ($350.00) and S/. 1,000 ($350.00) respectively. These funds will be invested in pants, shirts, sweaters, blouses, skirts, soda-pop, beer, and flour. The dreams of Mayra, Marina and Edith are to construct there own homes, have their own oven, have good health, and improve their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

Mayra, Marina y Edith pertenecen al Banco Comunal Tu Ángel Lucy desD. hace 3, 6 y 3 años respectivamente. Ellas dicen que en su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser responsables, solidarias y puntuales. Mayra es madre soltera, tiene 23 años y 1 hijo. Ella venD. ropa a pedido, sus ventas los realiza al crédito y cobra diariamente, actividad que realiza desD. hace 2 años. Por otro lado Marina tiene 50 años y 4 hijos y elabora panes desD. hace 3 años y los venD. en el mercado 12 D. abril. En un inicio vendía gelatina y con los préstamos que sacó D. su Banco Comunal comenzó su negocio actual. Mientras que Edith tiene 21 años y 1 hijo. Edith junto a su esposo tienen un bar desD. hace 5 años y su bar está ubicado en el centro D. la ciudad. Mayra, Marina y Edith necesitan préstamos D. 1400 soles, 1000 soles, 1000 soles respectivamente, que serán invertidos en la compra D. pantalones, polos, chompas, blusas, faldas, gaseosas, cervezas, harina. Los sueños D. Mayra, Marina y Edith son construir su casa, tener su horno propio, tener buena salud y mejorar sus negocios.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for their respective businesses (pants, shirts, sweaters, blouses, skirts, soda-pop, beer, and flour).

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
Graciela is a widow, 46 years old and has 7 children, the youngest of her children is 12, Graciela has been a partner of the Bonanza Comunal Bank for 2 years. She says that in her Communal Bank they taught her how to educate her children, to prevent illnesses, and to be punctual and to save. Graciela has a grocery store in the district of Acocro, she sells groceries, fruits, and vegetables. Previously Graciela raised small animals and with the loan that she took out from the Communal Bank she began her grocery business. Bit by bit she was supplying her business and now her business has grown. Graciela mentions that now she can give good nutrition and education to her children. Furthermore, Graciela is a farmer, she grows potatoes, corn and barley. Graciela needs a loan of 2000 soles that she will invest in the purchase of oil, rice, sugar, milk, soap, cookies, gum, candies, fruits and vegetables. Her savings she will utilize to buy a house in the city of Ayacucho and for the education of her children. The dreams of Graciela are to have her own house, to better her business and that her children have a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Graciela es viuda, tiene 46 años y 7 hijos, el menor D. sus hijos tiene 12 años, Graciela es socia del Banco Comunal Bonanza hace 2 años. Ella dice que en su Banco Comunal le enseñaron cómo educar a los hijos, cómo prevenir enfermedades, a ser puntual y a ahorrar. Graciela tiene una tienda D. abarrotes en el distrito D. Acocro, venD. abarrotes, frutas, verduras. Anteriormente Graciela criaba animales menores y con los préstamos que sacó D. su Banco Comunal ella inició su negocio D. abarrotes. Poco a poco fue surtiendo su negocio y ahora su negocio ha crecido. Graciela menciona que ahora pueD. dar una buena alimentación y educación a sus hijos. Además Graciela es agricultora, siembra papa, maíz, arveja. Graciela necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles que serán invertidos en la compra D. aceite, arroz, azúcar, leche, jabón, galletas, chicle, caramelo, frutas y verduras. Sus ahorros los utilizará para comprar una casa en la ciudad D. Ayacucho y para la educación D. sus hijos. Los sueños D. Graciela son tener casa propia, mejorar su negocio y que sus hijos tengan una buena educación.

loans.use: Graciela need a loan of 2000 soles that she will invest in the purchase of oil, rice, sugar, milk, soap, cookies, gum, candies, fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Maximiliana's Group

texts.es:
Marleni, Maximiliana and Alejandra have belonged to the Bonanza Comunal Bank since they were 2, 5, and 1 years old respectively. In their Comunal Bank they learned how to avoid sickness, manage their business, attend to their children and save. Marleni is a single woman of 28 years old, and she sells cosmetics from a catalogue, products she offers to her friends and relatives. Furthermore, she sells clothes in the Market of Vinchos, Huamanguilla and her desire is to open a clothing store. On the other hand, Maximiliana is 60 years old and has 3 children, and sells potato with egg in the Santa Clara market; she has maD. her sales by traveling for the last 30 years. While, Alejandra is widowed, 52, and sells fruits, coca and vegetables in the regional fairs and at the fairs she buys cereals that are sold in the Nery Garcia market. Previously, Alejandra was selling food in the jungle but she had to leave the business to be with her children in Ayacucho. Marleni, Maximiliana and Alejandra need loans of 1000 soles, 400 soles, 600 soles respectively, that will be invested in the purchase of shirts, pants, children’s sets, sweaters, jackets, potatoes, eggs, bananas, oranges, apples, onions, and carrots. The savings of Marleni, Maximiliana and Alejandra will be used to start a new business and for the expenses of their children. The dreams of Marleni, Maximiliana and Alejandra are to buy land, construct a house and to become more capable.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Marleni, Maximiliana y Alejandra pertenecen al Banco Comunal Bonanza desD. hace 2, 5 y 1 año respectivamente. En su Banco Comunal aprendieron a evitar las enfermedades, cómo manejar su negocio, a atender a los hijos y a ahorrar. Marleni es soltera y tiene 28 años, y venD. cosméticos por catálogo, productos que ofrece a amigos y familiares. Además venD. ropa en las ferias D. Vinchos, Huamanguilla u su deseo es abrir una tienda D. ropa. Por otro lado Maximiliana tiene 60 años y 3 hijos, y venD. papa con huevo en el mercado Santa Clara; sus ventas los hace ambulatoriamente desD. hace 30 años. Mientras que Alejandra es viuda, tiene 52 años y 5 hijos, y venD. frutas, coca y verduras en las ferias D. la región y D. las ferias compra cereales que son vendidos en el mercado Nery García. Anteriormente Alejandra vendía comida en la selva pero tuvo que dejar su negocio para estar junto a sus hijos en Ayacucho. Marleni, Maximiliana y Alejandra necesitan préstamos D. 1000 soles, 400 soles, 600 soles respectivamente, que serán invertidos en la compra D. polos, pantalones, conjuntos D. niños, chompas, casacas, papa, huevo, plátano, naranja, manzana, cebolla, zanahoria. Los ahorros D. Marleni, Maximiliana y Alejandra son para iniciar un nuevo negocio y para los gastos D. sus hijos. Los sueños D. Marleni, Maximiliana y Alejandra son comprar un terreno, construir su casa y capacitarse más.

loans.use: Marleni, Maximiliana and Alejandra need loans of 1000 soles, 400 soles, 600 soles respectively, that will be invested in the purchase of shirts, pants, children’s sets, sweaters, jackets, potatoes, eggs, bananas, oranges, apples, onions, and carrots.

loans.name: Norma Justina

texts.es:
Senora Norma A. is 70 years old, and is originally from Bluefields.  She is a widow, and although she has 7 children, she only lives with two of them ,and some grandchildren.  She has run her shop for 28 years, where seh sells basic goods, soda, beef, chicken, goat and other products.  One of the advantages of having this business is that it is located in an area ov about three and a half acres where there are only two shops, therefore there are many customers.  Like many similar shops, Dona Norma sells to her customers on credit, but only to those that are good payers, since in the past some were slow with the business.  In order to improve her small business, she needs more products, and for this reason requires financing in order to purchase:  4 quintal (about 400 kilos) of rice at US$42 per quintal, 2 quintals of sugar at US$26 per quintal, 1 quintal of beans at US$80 per quintal, 2 bags of bath tissue at US$10 per bag, 2 cans of oil at US$27 each, 2 cases of soda at US$19 each, 3 cases of 3 minute soup at US$25 each, 2 cases of Maggie soup at US$7 each, and 3 cases of sardines at US$19 per case


Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva translator

La señora Norma A. tiene 70 años de edad, es originaria de Bluefields, es viuda y aunque  tiene  7 hijos solamente vive con dos de ellos y unos nietos.Desde hace 28 años administra una pulperia en donde vende granos basicos, gaseosas, carne de res, pollo, chiverias y otros productos. Una de las ventajas que tiene este negocio es que en ese sector solamente existen dos pulperias las cuales cubren un radio de dos manzanas, lo que hace que tengan bastantes clientes. Al igual que muchas pulperias doña Norma le da credito a sus clientes, pero solamente a los buenos pagadores ya que en el pasado muchos quedaron morosos con el negocio. Para superarse en este pequeño negocio necesita mas productos y para tal fin requiere de un financiamientos para comprar:  4 quintales de arroz a US$ 42 dolares cada quintal, 2 quintales de azucar a US$ 26 dolares el quintal, 1 quintal de frijolesa US$ 80 dolares el quintal, 2 bolsones de belvet (papel higienico) a US$ 10 dolares cada bolson, 2 bidones de aceite a US$ 27 dolares cada bidon, 3 cajas de sopa 3 minutos a US$ 25 dolares cada caja, 2 cajas de sopa maggie  US$ 7 dolares cada caja, 2 cajas de gaseosas a US$ 19 dolares cada caja, y 3 docenas de sardinasa US$ 19 dolares cada caja.

loans.use: To purchase 4 quintals of rice, 2 quintals of sugar, 1 quintal of beans, 2 bags of bath tissue, 2 cans of oil, 3 cases of 3 Minute Soup, 2 cases of Maggie soup, 2 cases of soda, and three cases of sardines

payments.comment: La cuota real de pago es de $ 41.75 dólares.
La cuota real de pago es de $ 41.75 dólares
La cuota real de pago es de $ 41.75 dólares.
La cuota real de pago es de $ 41.75 dólares
correction due to overpayment for business 30609
Correction due to underpayment for business 30609

loans.name: Andina

texts.en:
Andina is a forty-two year old mother of three school-going children (two girls and a boy).  Her husband is an electrician and works for a construction company installing wires for electrical systems.
A few months ago, Andina started a business of running a small grocery store.  As she didn’t have access to capital, she was obliged to use a room of her house to operate the store.  She is still running the grocery store within her house but hopes that before long she will have a big and comfortable space where people can go to make purchases easily.
Andina explains that the competition in her community is very strong.  Nevertheless, she believes she can attract a lot of customers and her store keeps on growing.
With this loan (the second she will take from FSMA), she plans on adding new goods to her inventory in order to better satisfy her customers’ needs.  Andina’s business supports her children's school tuition and helps to pay for the rental of the house.

loans.use: to replenish a small grocery store

loans.name: Cristobalina

texts.en:
Cristobalina, a forty-three year old woman, owns and operates a general store in Los Alcarrizos, Santo Domingo.  She is a single mother of three children. 
Cristobalina is a living example of a hardworking and never-tiring person.  “Sometimes, you have to sacrifice yourself to achieve your goals,” she says as she explains that she had to leave her job to dedicate herself wholly to her new activity.  After two years of sacrifice and pain, she is experiencing success: well established clientele, a profitable business, and a more comfortable lifestyle for her family and so forth.
She wants to maintain this way of life.  With this loan, she will stock up the store so she can continue to satisfy her customers’ needs and attract new clients.

loans.use: the loan will be used to restock a small grocery store

loans.name: Analini

texts.en:
Analini is a young mother of three children (two of them girls), who attend school in the community of Los Alcarrizos, Santo Domingo.  Two years ago, Analini began selling beauty products and clothing for women.  In those days, she was facing big financial issues and didn’t have access to capital to invest in her business.  Therefore, she started off selling her products in the streets and visiting the neighbor door-to-door.
A few months ago, Analini took a loan from FSMA with which she purchased more goods to offer to her clientele.  She also invested a part of the money remodeling the living room of her house, where she now runs the business.

Analini explains that her big dream is to have a big store with “millions of people visiting every year,” she says, bursting out laughing.  For the moment, she is directing her attention to offer better services to the customers and attracting new clients.  With this loan, she will purchase new goods and offer greater variety.  She hopes this will increase her income and allow her to maintain a comfortable lifestyle for her family.

loans.use: to purchase clothing and beauty products for a small store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Marilu Flores

texts.en:
Marilu is in her early forties. She and her husband have four children, two girls and two boys.  They all attend secondary school.  Marilu owns a car and motorcycle repair shop. Her garage provides a lot of services and also sells products such as lubricants, brakes, used bumpers etc.  Marilu started the business a few months ago with her husband’s help.  As the couple didn’t have sufficient money to operate the new enterprise, Marilu took a loan to purchase the neccessary materials.
Marilu has some experience selling products and attracting clients.  Currently, her employees (two mechanics) repair an average of eight cars a day.  Marilu’s work consists of selling articles the customers need.  She is currently requesting a loan to purchase more materials and products in order to improve the quality of services she can offer to her clients.  Marilu’s business supports the studies of her children.

loans.use: To purchase materials and articles for a small car repair shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Elena has been selling dry goods for a few years. She is s 34 year old mother and has five children, all of which she has instilled with desires of progress and betterment. Since Elena has access to an oven, Elena also exports home-maD. bread to different zones in her region. Elena, along with her husband, expend their energy each day to proviD. from the well-being of each member of their family. Elena plans to convert her small grocery store into a Minimarket and in order to foment this plan in as short a time as possible she requests a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

Elena, se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes desD. hace un par D. años, a sus 34 años es madre D. cinco hijos, los mismos que le han otorgado deseos D. progreso y superación.También se dedica la exportación D. pan casero por las diferentes zonas D. esta región puesto que cuenta con un horno a su disposición. Elena en compañía D. su esposo se esfuerza a diario para otorgarles bienestar a cada uno D. D. los miembros D. su familia. La señora Elena tiene el propósito D. convertir su pequeña bodega en un Minimarket, y por esta razón solicita un préstamo a fin D. cristalizar su deseo en corto tiempo.

loans.use: Expansion of her business into a Minimarket.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
Nancy is 29 years old and the mother of two children. She owns a motorcycle-taxi which her husband Juan drives each day. Additionally Nancy and her husband seasonally sell fish in the market.

Nancy’s children intend to finish their studies completely. For Nancy, the most important thing to do at this time is provide her children with security and comfort so that they are not distracted from their studies. She needs to repair the tool of her husbands work, the motorcycle, so that it no longer causes him problems in his work. Unfortunately, up till now the motorcycle has suffered from various imperfections in its past care.

Let us help this noble woman so that she can soon obtain an additional motorcycle and improve the quality of her families life.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Nancy de 29 años, es madre de dos niños, es propietaria de un mototaxi en el que desempeña a diario su querido esposo, Juan. De manera adicional se dedica a la venta de pescados en el mercado de su ciudad únicamente por temporadas. Para la señora Nancy lo más importante ahora es otorgarles seguridad y comodidad a fin de que sus queridos hijos se desempeñen sin ningún problema con tranquilidad dentro de las carreras que se han propuesto concluir.Ella anhela reparar la única herramienta de trabajo de su esposo a fin de que este no le cause problemas en su cotidiano desempeño, ya que hasta ahora esta herramienta ha sufrido varios desperfectos de suma consideración.Ayudemos a esta noble madre para que pronto pueda adquirir una herramienta adicional con el objetivo de mejorar su calidad de vida familiar.

loans.use: Improve the condition of her motorcycle-taxi.

loans.name: Janeth

texts.es:
Janeth is 25 years old and has a little daughter, Margiori, who has become her main reason to improve and succeed. Janeth owns a motorcycle that can be used as a taxi. As it is her main source of income, she would like to improve the motorbike’s standing so she can raise the standard of living of her household.

Let’s grant her petition so that in a short time this young mother can build the transportation company she longs to have.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer.

Janeth de 25 años de edad, tiene una hijita de nombre Margiori, quien se ha convertido en su mejor motivo de progreso, es propietaria de un mototaxi.Su continuo deseo de procurarle bienestar a su pequeña la conducen a solicitar un préstamo para mejorar las condiciones de su herramienta de trabajo a fin de elevar el nivel de vida de su hogar.

Posibilitemos su petición para que dentro de poco esta joven madre pueda constituir su ansiada empresa de transportes.

loans.use: Buy spareparts to improve the standing of her taxi-motorcycle

loans.name: Eridania

texts.en:
When Eridania start selling fried vegetables and sandwiches a few years ago, she didn’t really think that it was a viable business.  In fact, she didn’t have money to buy raw materials to prepare the goods.  As a result, she sadly ceased that activity three months later.
The entrepreneur, nonetheless, didn’t give up and kept looking for funds until she met our organization and took a loan which allowed her to reestablish her business.  Eridania used her loan wisely and her small open-air cafeteria has been successful.  She is repaying the initial loan and is serving meals to a lot of people in her community.
Eridania explains that her ultiumate dream is to have a big, spacious and comfortable cafeteria where she can attend to many people daily and greatly increase her income.  With this loan, she will purchase raw materials for her sandwiches.  She will also buy disposable plastic dishes to serve the food on.  Given the loan, Eridania will be one step closer to realizing her dream.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to continue producing food for a small cafeteria.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 24, 2008)
